questions.text: What is the interpretation of the following PTA conducted on a patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Air Conduction (AC)

Bone Conduction (BC)

Frequency Range

125 - 8000 Hz

250 - 4000 Hz

Indicates

Overall hearing sensitivity

Cochlear function

Normal Ear
  • Both AC and BC thresholds are within the normal range (Within 20db in all frequencies)
  • No significant A-B gap

Conductive Hearing Loss
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated (poorer hearing) compared to normal.
  • BC Thresholds: Within normal limits.
  • A-B Gap (>20db): Significant

Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL)
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated to the same degree as AC.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal or absent

Presbycusis


 
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated, particularly in high frequencies.
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated with greater loss in higher frequencies.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal
  • Downsloping

Meniere’s Disease
  • Upsloping
  • A-B Gap: Typically minimal

questions.text: Carhart's notch is seen in which of the following conditions:
questions.explanation:
Feature

Otosclerosis

Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL)

Air Conduction

Loss, more pronounced at lower frequencies

-

Bone Conduction and Characteristic pattern

Normal, may show "Carhart's notch" at 2000 Hz (5-15 dB loss)

Typical notch at 4000 Hz in both air and bone conduction (Boiler's notch)

Hearing Loss

Mixed

Sensorineural

questions.explanation:
Procedure

Description

Complications

Stapedotomy

A small opening made in the stapes footplate; a prosthesis is inserted.

Lower complication rates; preferred by many otologists.

Stapedectomy

Complete removal of the stapes bone; replaced with a prosthetic device.

Higher risk of complications.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female from Nagaland presented with right-sided hearing loss and tinnitus. On examination, dull tympanic membrane with lymph nodes in the posterior triangle of the neck was seen. Which of the following is the management for the condition?

A 9-month-old baby was admitted in the ICU with history of recurrent sinusitis and otitis media by staph aureus. Laboratory examination showed decreased serum IgA, IgG, IgM, IgE, and plasma B cells. Which of the following is the condition is described here?

A patient presents to the OPD with hearing loss. On examination: Rinne test- Positive in the left ear and negative in the right ear Weber's test - lateralization towards the left Bone conduction test - Reduced in the right ear and similar in the left ear. Interpret the findings.

options.label: A
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss in left ear

options.label: B
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss in right ear

options.label: C
options.text: Conductive hearing loss in left ear

options.label: D
options.text: Conductive hearing loss in right ear.

questions.correct_answer: B. Sensorineural hearing loss in right ear
questions.explanation:
Test

Conductive Loss

Sensorineural Loss

Normal Hearing

Rinne

Negative (BC > AC)

Positive (AC > BC)

Positive (AC > BC)

Weber

Lateralises to worse ear

Lateralises to better ear

Heard equally

Absolute Bone Conduction

(ABC)

Hears as long as the examiner

Hears for a shorter duration

Hears as long as the examiner

Schwabach

Lengthened

Reduced

Normal

questions.text: A patient with CSOM was presented to the OPD with seizures. On examination and evaluation, homonymous hemianopia and epilepsy were present. Identify the condition with the CT scan given below?
Identify the sign given in the image below:
Identify the treatment option with the image given below:
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Type I

Defect: perforated tympanic membrane.

Repaired using a graft. (myringoplasty) (Option A ruled out)

Type II

Defect: Eroded malleus and perforated tympanic membrane.

Graft placed on incus or remaining malleus. (Option B ruled out)

Type III

Defect: Absence of malleus and incus.

Graft placed directly on stapes head (myringostapediopexy or columella tympanoplasty).

Type IV

Defect: Only the footplate of the stapes is present. It is exposed to the external ear.

A graft is placed between oval and round windows, allowing sound to act directly on the footplate and the round window is shielded. (Option D ruled out)

Type V

Fenestration operation: Creation of a new window on the horizontal semicircular canal, covering it with a graft when the stapes footplate is fixed but the round window is functional.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with right vestibular neuronitis. What findings are expected during the head impulse test in this patient?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: When the head is turned to the right, the eyeballs move to the left with nystagmus.

options.label: D
options.text: When the head is turned to the right, the eyeballs move to the right with nystagmus.

questions.correct_answer: C. When the head is turned to the right, the eyeballs move to the left with nystagmus.

questions.text: A diabetic patient with ear pain and an HBA1c of 10 presents with excruciating ear pain and blood-stained ear discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A middle-aged man came to the OPD with complaints of pain and hearing loss after trauma to the right ear. Examination revealed the presence of blood clots along with irregular perforations in the tympanic membrane. The next step in management is?

options.label: A
options.text: Aspirate the clot and perform audiometric tests

options.label: C
options.text: Maintain dry ear with systemic analgesics

questions.correct_answer: C. Maintain dry ear with systemic analgesics
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Definition
  • Tear or rupture of the tympanic membrane (eardrum) due to trauma

Etiology
  • Direct trauma (e.g., cotton bud, foreign body)
  • Barotrauma (e.g., diving, blast injury, airplane pressure changes)
  • Slap/blow to the ear
  • Sudden loud noise (acoustic trauma)

Symptoms
  • Sudden ear pain
  • Hearing loss (usually conductive)
  • Tinnitus
  • Bleeding or clear discharge from ear
  • Vertigo (if inner ear involved)

Signs
  • Visible perforation on otoscopy
  • Blood/debris in the ear canal
  • Possible absent light reflex

Investigations
  • Otoscopy (main diagnostic tool)
  • Tuning fork tests (Rinne/Weber for hearing loss type)
  • Audiometry (after healing or in unclear cases)

Treatment
  • Keep ear dry (avoid water entry)
  • Most heal spontaneously within weeks
  • Avoid ear drops unless infection suspected
  • Antibiotics if contaminated or signs of infection
  • Surgical repair (myringoplasty) if not healed in 6–8 weeks

Procedure

Description

Complications

Stapedotomy

Lower complication rates; preferred by many otologists.

Stapedectomy

questions.text: A 64-year-old female patient is brought to the ENT OPD with difficulties in comprehension. On examination, her fluency is found to be intact with poor comprehension and repetition. Her Pure tone audiometry and ABR is normal. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
In a 2-year-old child with a sudden onset of noisy breathing, which type of stridor is most likely to be represented by the image below?

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presenting with autophony, bilateral limb weakness and normal tympanic membrane that move with respiration. What is the probable cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Weight L

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with the complaints of vertigo which is sudden in onset, sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), and tinnitus which lasts minutes to hours with accompanied nausea, vomiting and vagal symptoms. Investigations show there is endolymphatic hypertension present. What is the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.explanation:
Vertigo
  • Episodic with sudden onset
  • Attacks occur in clusters, interspersed with periods of remission accompanied by nausea, vomiting, ataxia & nystagmus.
  • Loud noises might trigger vertigo due to the Tullio phenomenon.

Hearing Loss
  • Fluctuating hearing loss may improve between attacks but may progressively worsen over time, with some degree of permanent hearing loss.
  • Sensorineural hearing loss initially affecting lower frequencies.
  • Patients might experience distorted hearing or Diplacusis

Tinnitus
  • Low-pitched & Roaring type
  • It can be aggravated during acute attacks and might persist during periods of remission

Aural Fullness

Fluctuates & may vary in intensity

Emotional Impact

The recurrent nature of symptoms can lead to emotional stress and apprehension about future attacks, contributing to overall distress.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. He is diagnosed with otosclerosis and recommended stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests on this patient?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Rinne’s Test - negative; Weber’s Test - lateralized to right ear

questions.correct_answer: D. Rinne’s Test - negative; Weber’s Test - lateralized to right ear

Degree of hearing loss  Hearing threshold in better ear (average of 500, 1000 and 2000 Hz)
Not significant  0-25 dB 
Mild  26-30 dB
Moderate  41-55 dB 
Moderately severe  56-70 dB 
Severe 71-91 dB 
Profound  Above 91 dB 
Total

questions.text: Mark the correct statement/ statements regarding Inner and Outer hair cells? I. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses. II. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells. III. Outer hair cells are more responsible for movement of Tectorial membrane. IV. · Outer and inner hair cells present in the ratio of 3:1.

options.label: A
options.text: I, II and IV are correct

options.label: B
options.text: I, II and III are correct

questions.correct_answer: A. I, II and IV are correct

questions.text: During the examination of a female patient with hearing loss, it was observed that she had a negative Rinne test result at frequencies of 256 Hz and 512 Hz, but a positive Rinne test result at 1024 Hz. What would be the anticipated gap between air conduction and bone conduction in this case?

A 35-year-old woman came with complaints of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. On examination, it is found that the patient has conductive hearing loss and the Rinne test results are negative. Additionally, a reddish mass is observed located behind the tympanic membrane. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Glomus tumor (Paraganglioma)

Definition

Tumors originating from the paraganglia are known as paragangliomas, with glomus tumors being a specific type of paraganglioma.

Tumour type

Benign (most common benign tumor of middle ear)

Origin

Paraganglionic cells or glomus bodies .

Prevalence

Commonly seen in middle-aged individuals (40-50 years), with a higher prevalence in females

Types

  1. Glomus tympanicum: Arise from the promontory of the middle ear (tympanic plexus).
  2. Glomus jugulare: Arises from the dome of the jugular bulb (sympathetic plexus covering the jugular vein).

Spread

  • Inferiorly: To the jugular foramen
  • Anteriorly: Invading into the nasopharynx (blockage of eustachian tube)
  • Posteriorly: Invading the mastoid
  • Superiorly: To the posterior and middle cranial fossa (IX-XII cranial nerve palsy)
  • Laterally: To the tympanic membrane (present as a bleeding polyp of the external auditory canal).
  • Medially: Invading the labyrinth and petrous pyramid (dizziness and facial palsy).

 

Clinical manifestations
  • Hearing loss (gradually progressive conductive hearing loss)
  • Pulsatile tinnitus (heartbeat like sounds): It is synchronous with pulse and can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.
  • Bleeding from ear (profuse bleeding in case of polyp)
  • Dizziness or vertigo and facial paralysis may appear.
  • Symptoms like headache, sweating, palpitation, hypertension, anxiety due to sympathetic excess (catecholamine release)

Histopathology

  • No capsule (locally invasive)
  • HPE reveals Zell Ballen pattern, where epithelioid chief cells and sustentacular supporting cells form clusters (Zell Ballen) encircled by extensive vascular sinusoids.
  • Preoperative biopsy of the tumour is not performed due to the risk of profuse bleeding from its highly vascular thin-walled blood sinusoids and potential injury to the high jugular bulb or aberrant internal carotid artery.

Otoscopy

  • Red reflex through intact tympanic membrane and bulging tympanic membrane (glomus tympanicum).
  • “Rising sun" appearance due to the tumor originating from the floor of middle ear (glomus jugulare).

Diagnosis

  • CECT (IOC) shows erosion of the carotico-jugular spine on the diseased side, known as Phelp’s sign.
  • MRI scan revealed microhemorrhages within the tumor which appear as white and gray dots on MRI, creating a "salt and pepper" appearance.
  • Angiography is used to identify the arteries supplying the tumor.

Anterior cranial fossa

Middle cranial fossa

Temporal bone fracture
  • Cribriform plate(most common)
  • Roof of ethmoid air cells
  • Frontal sinus

Sphenoid sinus(following trauma)

CSF reaches the middle ear, escaping through the eustachian tube into the nose(CSF otorhinorrhea)

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the clinic by her mother with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Which diagnosis is most likely for a patient experiencing painful vesicles in the external auditory meatus and over the tympanic membrane, along with facial nerve palsy? Furthermore, which specific site is affected in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Ramsay Hunt syndrome and basal ganglion

options.label: B
options.text: Ramsay Hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion

questions.correct_answer: B. Ramsay Hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion

questions.text: What is the function of utricle and saccule?
questions.explanation:
Parts of the Inner Ear

The inner ear, or labyrinth, is essential for hearing and balance and is located within the temporal bone. It consists of the bony labyrinth and the membranous labyrinth.

Bony Labyrinth

A rigid structure filled with perilymph (a sodium-rich fluid), it has three main parts:

  1. Vestibule: Central part connecting to the cochlea and semicircular canals.
    • Bony Recesses in the vestibule contains the utricle and saccule (part of the membranous labyrinth).
      • Spherical Recess: Contains the saccule, a membranous sac involved in detecting linear acceleration and deceleration.
      • Elliptical Recess: Contains the utricle, which works with the saccule to aid in balance and spatial orientation.
    • Oval Window: Located on the vestibule’s lateral wall, it connects to the middle ear.
    • Openings of the Semicircular Canals: The three semicircular canals (lateral, posterior, and superior) have five openings into the vestibule, enabling detection of head rotations.
    • Opening of the Vestibular Aqueduct: Positioned below the elliptical recess, it allows the passage of the endolymphatic duct, which carries endolymph within the membranous labyrinth.
  2. Semicircular Canals: Three canals (lateral, posterior, and superior) positioned at right angles to detect rotational head movement. Each has an ampulla containing the crista ampullaris for sensory function.
  3. Cochlea: A spiral structure essential for hearing, divided into three chambers (scala vestibuli, scala tympani, and scala media). The scala vestibuli and tympani contain perilymph and communicate via the helicotrema, while the scala media houses the organ of Corti, which converts sound vibrations into electrical signals.

 

Membranous Labyrinth

 

A delicate system within the bony labyrinth, filled with potassium-rich endolymph, it includes:

  1. Cochlear Duct (Scala Media): Inside the cochlea, it separates the scala vestibuli and scala tympani and contains the organ of Corti for hearing.
  2. Utricle and Saccule: Membranous sacs in the vestibule responsible for detecting linear acceleration and balance. They are connected via the utriculosaccular duct.
  3. Semicircular Ducts: Membranous ducts within the bony semicircular canals, contributing to balance.
  4. Endolymphatic Duct and Sac: Extending from the utricle and saccule, the duct ends in the endolymphatic sac, important in surgical treatments for conditions like Ménière's disease.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for a primipara who is experiencing hearing impairment that has worsened during her pregnancy? The Rinne's test yields negative results in both ears, while the Weber's test shows lateralization to the right side. The otoscopy reveals normal tympanic membranes, and audiometry indicates a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz.

Match the following Wullstein's Classification Procedure/other name A. Type II B. Type III C. Type IV D. Type V 1. Fenestration tympanoplasty 2. Graft placed over the incus 3. Cavum minor 4. Columella tympanoplasty
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Type I

Myringoplasty: Repair of a perforated tympanic membrane using a graft.

Type II

Graft placed on incus or remaining malleus with an eroded malleus and perforated tympanic membrane.

Type III

Graft placed directly on stapes head in absence of malleus and incus (myringostapediopexy or columella tympanoplasty).

Type IV

Graft placed between oval and round windows, exposing stapes footplate (cavum minor), allowing sound to act directly on footplate.

Type V

Fenestration operation: Creation of a new window on the horizontal semicircular canal, covering it with a graft when the stapes footplate is fixed but the round window is functional.

questions.text: Which of the following tests can be used if the otoacoustic emission test is absent during screening? Pure tone audiometry. Tympanometry Free field audiometry Speech audiometry
questions.explanation:
Normal

Cochlear pathology

Retrocochlear pathology

Speech discrimination

Score (Statement d)

90-100%

Below 90%

Very poor

Recruitment

Absent

Present

Absent

SISI score

0-15%

>70%

0-20%

Threshold tone decay

Test

0-15 dB

<25 dB

>25 dB

Stapedial reflex

Present

Present

Absent

Stapedial reflex decay

Normal

Normal

Abnormal

BERA

Normal interval between wave I and V

Normal interval between wave I and V

Wave V delayed or absent

Rollover phenomenon

Absent primarily but seen in old age

Absent

Present

questions.text: A 6 year old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high arched palate, and impaired hearing. His tympanogram is given below. What would be the most appropriate management for him?
questions.explanation:
Tympanogram Type

Characteristics

Indication

Type A

Normal peak

Normal middle ear function

Type As

Shallow peak

Ossicular fixation (e.g., otosclerosis)

Type Ad

Deep peak

Ossicular discontinuity or thin tympanic membrane

Type B

Flat, no peak

Middle ear fluid or thick tympanic membrane

Type C

Peak at negative pressure

Eustachian tube dysfunction, middle ear negative pressure

Malfunctioning of Eustachian tube

Allergy

Unresolved otitis media

Viral infections
  • Adenoid hyperplasia.
  • Chronic rhinitis and sinusitis.
  • Chronic tonsillitis: Enlarged tonsils obstruct the soft palate and affect Eustachian tube function.
  • Nasopharyngeal tumours: Benign or malignant, especially in adults with unilateral serous otitis media.
  • Palatal defects: e.g., cleft palate, palatal paralysis.
  • Down's syndrome.

Seasonal or perennial allergies obstruct the Eustachian tube and increase middle ear mucosal secretions.

Inadequate antibiotic therapy can lead to persistent, low-grade infection, stimulating more mucous production and increasing goblet cells.


Adenoviruses and rhinoviruses can invade the middle ear mucosa, leading to increased secretory activity.

Procedure

Details

Myringotomy and Aspiration of Fluid

An incision in the tympanic membrane to aspirate fluid; thick mucus may require saline or mucolytic agents like chymotrypsin solution.

Grommet Insertion

If fluid recurs after myringotomy and aspiration, a grommet is inserted for continued middle ear aeration; remains in place for weeks or months.

Tympanotomy or Cortical Mastoidectomy

Required for removing loculated thick fluid or other pathologies like cholesterol granuloma.

Surgical Treatment of Causative Factor

Procedures like adenoidectomy, tonsillectomy, and/or maxillary antra washout may be needed, typically performed during myringotomy.

questions.text: Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: 1. Cochlear nucleus 2. Spiral ganglion 3. Superior olivary nucleus 4. Inferior colliculus 5. Medial geniculate body
What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image according to the Sade classification?

A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of slowly progressive difficulty hearing in the right ear. She also has pulsatile tinnitus. On examination, a reddish mass was seen behind the tympanic membrane, and an audible bruit was heard over the mastoid when auscultation with a stethoscope was performed. Her Rinne test was negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type

Glomus Tympanicum

Glomus Jugulare

Location

Tumours arise from the promontory of the middle ear.

Tumours originate from the dome of the jugular bulb and can extend into the middle ear and surrounding structures.

Manifestations

Pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, and a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane.

Pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, and may involve multiple cranial nerves (IX, X, XI)

Otoscopy findings
  • Reddish, pulsatile mass behind the tympanic membrane.
  • This may lead to conductive hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in the ear.
  • Reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane, often pulsatile.
  • It is associated with neurological symptoms due to cranial nerve involvement, including glossopharyngeal nerve involvement.

Investigations of Glomus Tumour

CT scan
  • CECT (contrast-enhanced computed tomography) is the investigation of choice to distinguish between glomus tympanicum and glomus jugulare tumours and to differentiate them from an aberrant carotid artery, a high jugular bulb, or a dehiscent jugular bulb.
  • Phelps sign: On the normal side, the carotico-jugular spine (a dense bone structure between the jugular and mastoid) is intact. On the affected side, erosion of the carotico-jugular spine is observed.

MRI scan

  • It demonstrates the extent of the tumour within the soft tissue.
  • Salt and pepper sign: Microhemorrhages within the tumour are visualized as white and gray dots on MRI, resulting in a "salt-and-pepper" appearance.

Angiography

It is essential when CT indicates involvement of the jugular bulb, carotid artery, or intradural extension. It also aids in identifying additional glomus tumors, locating feeding vessels, and guiding embolization.

Brain Perfusion and Flow Studies

  • These are essential if the tumor compresses the internal carotid artery.
  • They assess brain perfusion, contralateral carotid artery function, and may involve xenon blood flow and isotope studies to gauge stroke risk and the need for artery replacement.

Biopsy
  • Histopathological studies show the Zell Ballen pattern, where epithelioid chief cells and sustentacular supporting cells form clusters (Zell Ballen) encircled by extensive vascular sinusoids.
  • Preoperative biopsy of the tumour is not performed due to the risk of profuse bleeding from its highly vascular thin-walled blood sinusoids and potential injury to the high jugular bulb or aberrant internal carotid artery.

questions.text: What are the objective tests used to assess hearing ability? A. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry) B. OAE (Otoacoustic emission) C. PTA (Pure tone audiometry) D. Tympanometry

A young lady presented to the ENT OPD with a history of sudden onset unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness following an episode of acute otitis media two weeks back. Rinne’s test and fistula test were positive. She had refused treatment then and currently came with complaints of worsened hearing loss in the affected ear. On examination, the fistula test was negative. What would be the most likely finding on the Rinne test in this scenario?
What is the Battle sign?

What would be your diagnosis for a patient who has presented with symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and fullness of ears. The symptoms improve on keeping the right ear up. He had previously been operated on for a safe type of right side chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) six months ago?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Etiology

Can occur after head trauma, barotrauma (e.g., diving), temporal bone anomalies, or ear surgery (e.g., stapedectomy).

Symptoms

Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, tinnitus, and sometimes a sense of fullness in the ear.

Complications

Recurrent meningitis (especially in children with temporal bone defects), cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak.

Diagnosis

Often clinical, based on history and symptoms; confirmed through surgical exploration if suspected.

Temporal bone CT: Shows pneumolabyrinth, accumulation of fluid in the middle ear, and/or ossicular chain disruption, but also can often be normal.

Treatment

Surgical closure of the fistula to prevent further complications, such as meningitis; limited improvement in hearing.

Prognosis

Hearing improvement post-surgery is usually limited; however, vertigo symptoms often improve or resolve.

questions.text: A young man presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. Histology image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Origin: Schwann cells; Site: CP angle

Pathology
  • Antoni A areas: These areas are composed of tightly packed spindle-shaped cells with elongated nuclei. The cells are arranged in palisades or whorls, forming Verocay bodies. The cells in Antoni A areas exhibit nuclear hyperchromasia (increased staining intensity) and cellular cohesion.
  • Antoni B areas: These areas are less cellular and show a looser arrangement of cells with a myxoid or microcystic appearance. The cells in Antoni B areas may have more irregular nuclei and a less distinct cytoplasmic organization compared to Antoni A areas.

Clinical presentation
  • 40-60 years, Males = Females
  • Unilateral sensorineural hearing loss associated with tinnitus

Radiology
  • Investigation of choice/Gold standard: MRI with Gadolinium contrast - ice cream cone appearance seen on CP angle.
  • Other investigations:
    • CT (with/without contrast): done when MRI is not feasible
    • Vertebral Angiography: though helps in localizing the tumor, it is not the investigation of choice.

Association
  • Neurofibromatosis type-2 (NF-2): Presents with bilateral Schwannomas and other tumors like Meningioma, ependymoma may also be associated.

Differential diagnoses

CP angle meningioma:

  • MRI: Dural tail sign seen

Glomus tumor: (Glomus jugulare)

  • Arises from the dome of Jugular bulb within the jugular fossa.
  • CT: Phelp sign (Bony erosion seen between carotid canal and jugular fossa)

questions.text: From which of the following structures does the saccule develop?
Which of the following does not represent a characteristic of tubercular otitis media?
Which of the following is not seen in Meniere's Disease?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Cause

Excess endolymph accumulation (endolymphatic hydrops)

Triad of Symptoms

1. Vertigo (episodic, lasts minutes to hours)

2. Tinnitus (low-frequency, roaring type)

3. Hearing loss (sensorineural, fluctuating, progressive)

Other Symptoms

Aural fullness (blocked ear sensation)

Not Typically Seen

Ear pain, except in secondary infections

Diagnosis

Clinical + Audiometry (low-frequency SNHL)

Treatment

Dietary modifications (low sodium), diuretics, vestibular suppressants, intratympanic steroids, and surgery in refractory cases

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of Meniere's disease?

options.label: D
options.text: Radiofrequency ablation is the treatment of choice

questions.correct_answer: D. Radiofrequency ablation is the treatment of choice
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D: Radiofrequency ablation is the treatment of ch

 

Acute attack

Chronic phase

Vestibular sedatives
  • Dimenhydrinate, promethazine, prochlorperazine
  • Diazepam suppresses activity of medial vestibular nucleus
  • Prochlorperazine

Vasodilators
  • Carbogen (5% CO2 with 95% O2)
  • Histamine drip
  • Nicotinic acid
  • Betahistine (Vertin)

Other drugs
  • Atropine
  • Diuretics

Conservative procedures (preserve hearing)

Destructive procedure (Destroy hearing)
  • Vestibular nerve sectioning
  • Decompression of endolymphatic sac
  • Endolymphatic shunt
  • Sacculotomy (Ficks procedure)
  • Cody tack procedure
  • Cochleosacculostomy (cochlear duct is punctured)
  • Labyrinthectomy

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of facial nerve palsy?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Idiopathic B

Causes

Symptoms

Diagnosis

Management

Idiopathic (Bell's palsy)

 

 
  • Sudden onset of facial weakness or paralysis
  • Difficulty closing one eye
  • Drooping of the mouth or eyelid
  • Clinical examination of facial muscles
  • History and physical examination
  • Assessing facial movements and muscle strength
  • Corticosteroids
  • Eye protection (eye patch or lubricating eye drops)
  • Facial exercises and physical therapy

questions.text: In parotid gland surgery, which of the subsequent structures serves as a reference point for the facial nerve?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Tragal

Facial Nerve

Landmark in Parotid Gland Surgery

Facial Nerve

- Emerges from stylomastoid foramen - Courses through the parotid gland

Landmark 1

Tragal pointer (small prominence at the anterior margin of the tragus of the ear)

Landmark 2

Retromandibular vein (used to locate the facial nerve branches)

Landmark 3

Anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (used to guide the dissection of the facial nerve)

Landmark 4

Transverse facial artery (crosses the parotid gland and aids in identifying the facial nerve)
